I'm going to start on this theme, "Fighting

I'm really excited because I think I might

106.text:
As Shaun said, this is me, I'm a Digital Transformation

112.text:
by, I'm Ex-BBC, I'm Ex-agency, I'm a former

122.text:
Last year I produced this report, "The New

127.text:

sector, some major charities like Macmillan,

132.text:

138.text:

143.text:
I was trying to find out what the real potential
was for technology, to really change the way

149.text: that we're delivering tech for good.

152.text:
I say that that's my title - Digital Transformation
Consultant, but actually today I am going

157.text:
by the title Digital Superhero Recruitment

I'm here on a recruitment drive, I'm looking
for people who have the potential to use their

167.text:
advanced technology and I mean technology
in it's broadest sense, the skills to save

173.text:
How many of you here work in UX or service

180.text:
People who work in tech, in general? Yeah
so quite a lot of people.

184.text:
If you're in one of those groups you are already
on this path - I believe that UX is a noble

190.text:
discipline, it is an art of putting other
people before yourself, that means not just

196.text:
the end users, it's about putting those people
in front - before your boss or whoever the

200.text:
highest paid person is in any room - and that's

207.text:
I will say that whilst your working tirelessly
and often thanklessly to design products that

213.text:
are so good that people don't even notice
them,

217.text:
if you're doing that because they're just
there to sell products, you're maybe slightly

224.text:
So today is really a pitch to try and get

228.text:
organisations if you're in them and come and

232.text:
So why do we actually need Digital Superheroes?
Lets make a justification here.

248.text: there are some dark forces at work.

252.text:
So what are those dark forces? Well there's
an awful lot of doom-mongering going on around

256.text:
tech at the moment - there's plenty of research
that shows we're increasingly addicted to

261.text:
our screens which some have said could lead
to a fundamental breakdown in productive social

267.text:
That picture gets even more worrying when
we're talking about kids - where screen addiction

271.text:
and the future of immersive gaming could completely
change the adults that these kids grow up

278.text:
There's a lot of people saying that robots
are going to take all our jobs, frankly I

282.text:
would quite welcome that. In fact, AI robots
may take over absolutely everything, Steven

290.text:
"The development of full artificial intelligence
could spell the end of the human race."

296.text: So, the doom bells are ringing even!

302.text:
We know from the stuff that's gone on with
Edward Snowden that the governments and corporations

307.text:
are already hacking and manipulating personal
data and it's not niche - it has made it into

312.text:
season 4 of House of Cards, this is mainstream
stuff now!

318.text:
But the pace of technology change has been
increasing for a long time and I don't know

326.text:
exactly why people think that it's so much
of a change now, or maybe I do.

330.text:
You've probably seen a version of this curve
before, it's curve that shows the accelerating

341.text: In the 1400s the printing press, then a while...

346.text:
Then it starts to pick up a bit with the steam
engine, telegraph, light bulb, telephone, car...

354.text:
And then in the last 50 years, particularly
in the last decade things really take off.

360.text:
We're rapidly moving through DVDs, Hybrid
cars, Google, Youtube, Facebook, iPads, Driverless

366.text:
cars, 3D - it goes on and on, you're all familiar
with this.

371.text:
The difference may be that actually this pace
of change means that we don't have time to

375.text:
process. Before, when we were in the light
bulb-telephone era, there was time to think

381.text:
about what this meant for us as a society
and in our jobs and lives. Now we're moving

386.text:
so fast that we're stumbling slightly blindly
into the future, and that's where things might

393.text:
The truth is I'm a tech optimist, I see more
ups than downs in our future. But we're not

399.text: going to get there without some help I think.

402.text:
Luckily there's a movement rising to stop
these potential doomsday scenarios from happening.

409.text:
The movement is roughly called "Tech for Good"
that's what we call it these days, and it's

414.text:
a band of disparate people - thinkers, doers,
people like me and you who are working on

420.text:
ideas, services, trialling new products - they
use technology to improve the world, not to

429.text:
These digital superheroes aren't always obvious,
you might be sat next to one of them, you

431.text:
might even be one already, they come in all
shapes and sizes, they're UX's, devs, product

436.text:
owners. I know from looking at the attendee
list that there's already some amazing organisations

440.text:
here, people from the BBC, my old home, people
from the Co-op do an awful lot of good for

445.text:
the world, some people from major charities,
you guys are definitely on the path towards

450.text:
digital superhero-dom, but don't despair if
you're not one of them yet and you think you

456.text:
I'm going to do a briefing now, on how you
can get to be one.

459.text:
I'm going to do it by showing you a bunch
of examples of products, ideas and people

465.text:
who I think are making a change for good in
the world.

469.text:
So, "What do digital superheroes actually
look like?"

472.text:
Well, in four points, breaking away from the
traditional 3 or 5.

478.text:
The first one is pretty simple. Digital Superheroes
make products that really help people.

484.text:
Sometimes they do things in ways that you
didn't even think were possible.

487.text:
Sometimes they do them with technology we're
really familiar with.

490.text:
This is an app that I think probably none
of you will have on your phones, I might be

501.text:
It was created by the charity Ugly Mugs who
you may not have heard of, they're quite small,

505.text: to try and make sex work safer.

508.text:
Among the many issues of working in the sex
industry is that there isn't really a good

513.text:
system at the moment, for reporting and alerting
other sex workers to dangerous clients.

520.text:
What happens in this app is sex workers use
it to check whether a punter contacting them,

525.text:
in this example they have an incoming call
from a potential client, and it raises the

531.text:
alert level to show them that this has been
flagged by another sex worker to be somebody

536.text:
who is on the bad list. That might mean that
they are aggressive or violent, they may have

540.text:
raped a previous sex worker. This allows sex
workers to know whether to go ahead with meeting

548.text:
It also allows you to go through and check
all of the numbers of previous clients you've

553.text:
worked with to see if they're also on the
list.

557.text:
It's quite an amazing thing, they've worked
very closely with a small group of sex workers

561.text:
to do this and they're working exclusively
on marketing it to sex workers, there's no

564.text: other function they are trying to serve with it.

566.text:
I think it's a really lovely example of how
you can use technology to reach a group of

572.text:
people who are otherwise completely excluded
from technology that could do them a lot of

580.text:
At a bigger scale, this is one of my favourite
projects. These two men are wearing 3D printed

588.text:
prosthetic limbs, they're wearing prosthetic
limbs because they lost those limbs in the

595.text:
30 million people worldwide need prosthetics,
often in war-torn countries for obvious reasons.

602.text:
But the skills to make them in the traditional
way are really lacking, and normally when

608.text:
you're in a country in the middle of a war
or other crisis those workers just aren't

613.text:
there - all medical workers go to the front
lines.

618.text:
There's a positive note; these were created
by a man called Tony Canning who's from Northern

623.text:
Ireland, he ran a small 3D printing studio.
Upon seeing what was happening in Sudan and

628.text:
Syria decided to move his studio to those
regions.

633.text:
He is now printing 3D prosthetic limbs; arms,
legs, ankles, knees for a ridiculously cheap

642.text:
cost. A traditional prosthetic limb will cost
around £20,000, not money that most of us

649.text:
have. The ones they're printing now are for
about £40. And they're moulded to fit you,

655.text:
they work, they're functional - they're not
just dumb limbs.

657.text:
That's the kind of scale of change that I
can see in our future, going from something

663.text:
that would be £20,000, would take 3-6 months
to produce to being able to get something

669.text:
in 36 hours for 30 to 40 quid, it's really
quite something.

673.text:
Some people have asked me why do I think this
is a digital technology? I think 3D printing

677.text:
fits in my broader definition of digital technology
but also rather than trying to go proprietary

683.text:
and put a load of IP on this, they've open
sourced it.

688.text:
So anyone with a configurable 3D printer can
create these. They're making them in some

693.text:
UK schools at the minute as projects to teach
people about war. To teach the kids about

697.text:
war and conflict - I think it's an amazing
project.

703.text:
Another thing that Digital Superheroes can
be identified by is that they use any tool

708.text:
or platform that they can get their hands
on, as long as they think it can do something in a better way.

713.text:
The BBC launched a WhatsApp service at the
end of 2014 - at the height of the Ebola crisis.

723.text:
It specifically targeted Sierra Leone where
the crisis was really growing - it was becoming

729.text:
the biggest issue that Sierra Leone had faced
and they have faced a lot of serious issues

736.text:
They decided to try and tackle the issue rather
than going in with more on the ground staff

743.text:
which actually we're getting to places, instead
they used WhatsApp, because people in Sierra

750.text:
Leone have WhatsApp. They just provided an
information service, it had text information

754.text:
in English and French, it had some simple
infographics and it had audio in English and

759.text:
French. It just did things like explain if
you think somebody has died from this disease

765.text:
don't touch them. Quarantine people who you
think might be infected.

774.text:
It reached 20,000 in the first 3 months which
might not sound like a huge number of people

778.text:
but that's 20,000 people in areas where on
the ground information, advice and aid aren't

784.text:
getting there. That's 20,000 people with a
network significantly bigger.

788.text:
It was phenomenal the impact it had and the
BBC used WhatsApp, they used the technology

794.text:
that already existed - much cheaper, much
quicker to make, much more effective.

799.text: That's what I mean by using tools that exist.

801.text:
You can look at crowdfunding, it's not new,
things like Kick Starter have been around

806.text:
helping to get products off the ground for
a long time. But these two on screen I think

812.text:
show what you can do using crowdfunding as
a tool for good.

817.text:
The top left one is the medical fundraisers
page on IndieGogo - there's people there raising

822.text:
money for drugs that they can't afford, for
their kid's cancer treatment, some people

826.text:
are even managing to raise money for plastic
surgery which I was quite surprised about...

831.text:
And the one on the right through Fund Surfer
is just one of the many many crowdfunding

835.text:
projects that sprung up in response to the
Calais refugee crisis. Rather than giving

840.text:
50 quid to one of the big aid agencies people
decided to raise some money to buy products

849.text:
Technology is putting power into people's
hands in a way that just wasn't possible before,

853.text:
you don't have to go through a middleman any
more.

856.text:
My favourite current example of crowdfunding
is this one.

860.text:
It's from the states, it's a girl scout troop
in West Washington - this is their page on

867.text:
IndieGogo and I'm going to show you a video
which explains it better than I can.

877.text:
Now I definitely think that troop of girl
scouts count as being Digital Superheroes,

990.text:
they're young women who decided to make a
stand against a donor who wouldn't give $100,000

999.text: if it was going to go to any transgender girls.

1004.text:
By choosing to do a crowdfunding campaign
not only did they not just make back that

1009.text:
$100,000 they made over $400,000 they also
raised this issue to a national level. It

1016.text:
got discussed not just in Washington but around
the states and has changed the girl scouting

1022.text: movements policy around how they take donations.

1026.text:
That's a small group of girls that did that,
because they decided to use some existing

1031.text:
technology to raise the issue and raise funds
- I think it's pretty inspiring.

1036.text:
Thirdly, Digital Superheroes aren't frightened
to try new ways to do things, they're brave,

1044.text:
they don't stick with conventions if they
aren't working any more.

1049.text:
Now I imagine that quite a lot of you are
already actively working to help your organisations

1053.text:
do things differently. That might be about
bringing in more agile iterative processes

1058.text:
- I'm not going to talk about that, Tom is
going to talk about that and he is fantastic.

1063.text:
It might be about bringing service design
thinking into new fields, those are the kinds

1066.text:
of things I'm talking about. One of my favourite
recent examples is one from St. Mary's Hospital

1073.text:
St Mary's Hospital established itself in 1845,
it's been providing quality healthcare to

1078.text:
millions for over 150 years - it's like any
other reputable hospital in most ways.

1085.text:
But I think it's a good example of an organisation
that's using Digital Superheroes to change

1089.text:
itself for the better. It hasn't become a
wholly digital organisation, there are still

1094.text:
physical patients being treated by physical
healthcare staff in a physical building.

1099.text:
But what they've done is they have put in
the Helix Centre. This is a box that have

1105.text:
put in, in the middle of the grounds of the
hospital. Within that box is a bunch of design

1111.text:
thinking happening. It stands for Health Innovation
Exchange and it's effectively an innovation

1119.text:
They constructed this pod to make it really
visible to everybody in the hospital, what

1123.text:
happens is clinicians can go into the lab
with a problem that they face, it can be small

1128.text:
or it can be large and they work with this
team, in the studio to try and find digital

1136.text:
It exists solely to answer critical healthcare
challenges. They develop them in lean iterative ways.

1143.text:
So far they've done 15 projects that are live
pilots including increasing rates of bowel

1150.text:
cancer screening, offering guidance for clinicians
on how to communicate about end of life care,

1156.text:
creating effective asthma management tools
for kids, dealing with storage of IV fluids

1161.text:
on the wards. A really broad range of things
that all have combined digital and offline

1166.text:
solutions, and they've only been going
since last September! Remarkable what a small

1171.text:
number of individuals can do whether they
be girl scouts or designers, if you give them

1177.text: the chance to use technology for good.

1182.text:
At an even bigger scale - this is one of my
favourite all time Digital Superheroes, his

1187.text:
name is José Antonio Rodríguez Salas and
he's the mayor of a Spanish town called Jun.

1193.text:
Jun has 3,500 residents and Mr. Salas, when
he took over as mayor believed that there

1201.text:
were probably better ways for Jun to be communicating
as a community.

1207.text:
Over the years he trialled various technical
systems for doing online communication and

1213.text:
then finally he hit upon Twitter, and began
to revolutionise civic life in the town.

1219.text:
Residents and workers in Jun all have Twitter
accounts, all 3,500 of them have a Twitter

1225.text:
account - that meant training some of the
people who weren't even fully literate how

1230.text:
to be literate so that they could use Twitter
and they use it for everything in civic life.

1235.text:
You can book your doctors appointment through
it, you can make a complaint about streets

1240.text:
not being cleaned. The town hall uses it for
all its internal comms, it's quite remarkable.

1246.text:
It is completely open and transparent so you
can go and have a look and see what the residents

1251.text:
of Jun are talking about today with each other
- things they happy about, complaining about.

1255.text:
They also saw a big rise in public workers
in Jun being thanked as a result of everybody

1261.text:
I think it's fairly phenomenal that not only
did they manage to squeeze in some digital

1265.text:
inclusion with that, they have 3,500 people
all communicating openly on a technical platform

1274.text: I love them, I think I might move there.

1278.text:
Fourth point, you can find Digital Superheroes
everywhere.

1283.text: They don't have to work in our field.

1285.text:
Most of what I've been talking about has been
how professionals with tech skills can turn

1291.text:
their hands to delivering social outcomes,
with a few other examples like the girl scouts,

1294.text: of people who have just seen technology opportunities.

1299.text:
The truth is technology is no longer the preserve
of nerds like us, apologies for calling you

1302.text:
nerds but we all are.. It's everybody's game,
and that means there's umpteen digital superheroes

1309.text:
I'm going to share another example and it's
one that really opened my eyes to the potential

1319.text:
This is part of Rio, it's one of the bigger
favelas, it's a photo from a project that

1327.text:
Google conducted at the start of 2015, a research
project where they were going out to see the

1331.text:
impact or lack of impact internet connectivity
was having in favelas.

1336.text:
They admit that they expected to find quite
a limited picture, they thought that actually

1342.text:
the fact that the internet goes down every
time it rains would be stopping people from

1347.text: using technology to progress their own lives.

1353.text:
What they found in just one small block was
a hive of industry happening as a result of

1360.text:
internet connectivity. There was a full digital
radio station, two cyber cafes with high grade

1367.text:
computer equipment, a hotel that had been
turned into a community hall where they were

1371.text:
running computer science classes, there was
another room where Coca-cola was sponsoring

1376.text:
digital marketing classes, there was a womens
collective running an online-only fashion

1382.text:
house that's become so successful that it
now ships internationally.

1385.text:
These people are all completely leapfrogging
the desktop processes that we went through,

1391.text:
because they had access to cheap technology
and were using it to change their own lives

1394.text: and those of the people around them.

1397.text:
This Digital Superhero idea is something that
you don't have to stand up and declare that

1403.text:
you care about tech for good, it's happening
all around us.

1408.text: So what impact can it have at scale for organisations?

1412.text:
The open university is one of my favourite
stories about how a small group of digital

1423.text:
You might be familiar with the traditional
open university picture, a fairly innovative

1428.text:
organisation when it was born, the idea of
educating to degree level people via technology

1435.text:
- the first technology being via the TV was
pretty remarkable, and they continue to evolve

1441.text:
that idea moving into distance learning that
we're familiar with today.

1445.text:
But what happened after a while was that evening
though they realised that the distance learning

1450.text:
model was starting to be less effective they
weren't picking up as many people each year,

1455.text:
people were starting to want to learn in different
ways - they couldn't change their organisation

1460.text:
from the inside. They were struggling in a
world of academia where people like to really

1465.text:
think things through, not rush ahead and try
new stuff.

1470.text:
It just so happened that a Digital Superhero
was there and he happened to be their vice

1475.text:
chancellor, and he realised that they weren't
going to make this change for themselves from

1478.text:
the inside and that there was a really severe
risk that another 10-20 years down the line,

1483.text: maybe even sooner, they might go out of business.

1486.text:
So instead he launched Future Learn. I don't
know if you know Future Learn, it's a MOOC

1492.text:
platform, lots of open online courses, some
short some long, all university accredited

1498.text:
course where you can study things as random
as "Soils: Introducing the world beneath our

1503.text:
feet" or forensic science - one of their most
popular courses.

1508.text:
It's quite an amazing platform, it's beautifully
designed, again developed from the very small

1512.text:
start up of 4 people to being I think they're
about 80 people now and based at the British

1516.text:
Library. It's a really fantastic product,
but beyond that it's completely changing what

1524.text: it means to do distance learning.

1526.text:
The Open University still runs its central
business but there's a kind of unspoken acceptance

1534.text:
that the open university might just become
Future Learn at some point in the next ten years.

1541.text:
I mentioned the British Library because that's
where they're based, an institution that might

1545.text:
be a bit surprising as one that's really digitally
transforming itself given that it's an institution

1554.text:
But actually it's one of the most advanced
non-profits in terms of digital transformation

1558.text:
and that's because it has a raft of digital
superheroes there, the curators.

1564.text:
I asked the chief exec who is part of the
new reality what it was about them that allowed

1569.text:
them to be so open to technology fuelled change
and he said that curators are naturally curious

1575.text:
about things, they like to try tools, they're
not worried about change because they have

1582.text:
What that's lead to is that yes, British Library
still fulfils a library function, it doesn't

1588.text:
mean it doesn't care about being a custodian
of the physical things that they have to keep

1593.text: and look after for the nation.

1595.text:
Roly Keating, the chief exec, now describes
them as being a data institution, they are

1601.text:
owners of information, they are the home for
the Alan Turing Institute, some of the biggest

1607.text:
collection of the smartest data scientists
in the world, taking all of the information

1612.text:
in that big heritage storage-load of stuff
and new data sources from everywhere and combining

1622.text:
They've really been breaking down the boundaries
between themselves and organisation through

1625.text:
digital as well, things like their Flickr
commons collection has had 230 million users,

1630.text:
their #ShareMyThesis project is great, they
were trying to get academics to be more transparent

1637.text:
about the work they were doing and pithier
because academics really like long sentences,

1643.text:
so they've been getting everybody to share
their thesis in a tweet. It's quite interesting

1650.text:
This has happened because they had a series
of staff who really understood that technology

1656.text:
could change the institution, and they had
a chief exec who really bought into that vision

1661.text:
But it's not just non-profits doing this great
work in tech for good, it's making a big impact

1669.text:
in major commercial brands too. And it needs
to because actually when you look at the new

1675.text:
workforce, 60% of Gen Z want jobs that make
a social impact from a major study done in 2014

1683.text:
49% of millennials would choose to work for
a sustainable company over an unsustainable one.

1692.text:
There's pressure on commercial companies to
do this, it's not just doing it because it's

1696.text:
nice. There's also commercial benefits to
doing it.

1700.text:
Barclays Digital Eagles was a great example
of this.

1702.text: Barclays is a big traditional bank.

1707.text:
Barclays realised that they needed to change,
not because they thought it was particularly

1712.text:
important for the world, that they did some
more CSR.

1717.text:
They realised that there was for-profit benefit
in moving customers to being online only bankers.

1723.text:
That meant tackling digital inclusion in the
UK.

1725.text:
Their Digital Eagles, of which they trained
20,000 of their staff - no small feat or investment

1734.text:
that they have made internally to do this.
They're out doing what they call Tea and Teach

1742.text:
In one month they did 93 different care homes,
both for elderly people and disability care

1749.text:
homes, to try and bring that final group of
people online so that they can access banking

1755.text:
services but also so that they can access
everything else that the internet brings us.

1763.text:
It's a program that has made substantial impact
internally for them as well, those 20,000

1769.text:
staff who are digital eagles are now responsible
for doing all of the internal technology change

1777.text:
They've stopped having a completely separate
IT function, not for the actual way the bank

1782.text:
is run, that's a complicated thing you have
to be really careful about but the day to

1786.text:
day running of the business is effectively
owned by 20,000 of their staff rather than

1793.text:
It's a really positive and progressive way
of using technology inside a commercial organisation

1798.text:
and whilst I don't love Barclays as a bank
I really like and respect them for doing this,

1802.text:
I think it's a really positive example of
being an organisation that can for-purpose

1819.text:
So the big question - is it you? If you think
you're not yet a fully fledged digital superhero,

1829.text:
and I think that there's definitely some people
in this room who are and I would love to talk

1832.text:
to you about things that we could do together,
things that you're doing in your organisations,

1835.text:
but if you're not yet and you're interested
in getting more into this field there's loads

1843.text:
You could choose to go and work agency side
or move agencies to someone like Sigma who

1847.text:
actually do a lot of work with for-good clients,
both for-profit and for-purpose, there are

1853.text:
plenty of agencies like them although we highly
recommend them and we thank them for putting

1860.text:
You could go and join a non-profit, there's
an increasing number of interesting UX and

1864.text:
technology roles happening in charities - that's
the sector that I work in most. If you're

1869.text:
interested in that do come and talk to me
about it.

1873.text:
You could just choose to give some of your
skills and your time - good causes need smart

1878.text:
people who understand this stuff, there is
a bit of a dearth of great technology understanding

1884.text:
in lots of the major non-profits and particularly
in smaller charities. You could be incredibly

1889.text:
valuable to them, a few hours of advice from
you, a little project that you work on for

1895.text:
them, you could be the digital superhero for
a charity.

1901.text:
Or you could choose to use your skills in
the organisations that you're already working

1906.text:
in, raising the questions about what more
could your organisation do to use technology

1911.text: to be for-purpose as well as for-profit.

1915.text:
There's also plenty of ways to go and meet
other people who are interested in this, there's

1919.text:
some really fantastic meet ups - Citizen Beta,
there's one called Tech For Good which has

1924.text:
started doing sessions up here in Manchester,
also in Brighton and in London, where you

1928.text:
can meet other people to collaborate with,
to discuss ideas with.

1932.text:
And there's also ways that you can volunteer
your time online, time banking services, things

1937.text:
like hashtag charity which is quite new. Reach
skills, where if you're interested in using

1942.text:
your UX technology, product ownership, project
management - people need good project managers

1947.text: - there's plenty of place to offer that.

1951.text:
Don't feel like "I can't get into this field
I don't want to take a charity job because

1955.text: I'll have to cut my salary" (which is true)

1959.text:
There's plenty of ways that you can become
a digital superhero if you're not already one.

1964.text:
A quick thank you to the Noun Project for
the little superhero from Moriah Rich and

1971.text: also Darth Vader from Rohith MS.

1975.text:
If you don't know the noun project, lots of
you are designers so you probably do, it is

1978.text: the best thing on the internet right now.

1981.text:
That's about it! Please do come and talk to
me over lunch or later on I will be in the

1987.text:
pub I think afterwards for a little bit. If
you're interested in this the new reality

1993.text:
is filled with more examples of organisations,
individuals inside and outside the non-profit

1999.text:
sector doing things for good. It also explains
quite a lot about why charities have got a

2004.text:
way to go before they get there, so if you
work in a charity then please do read it.

2010.text: I'd like to take some questions.

2015.text:
Thank you Julie, that was inspiring and uplifting
stuff I'm sure you'd agree.

2022.text: Do we have any questions from the floor please?

2035.text:
Hi, I work for Stockport Council, we have
a transformation program with a department

2049.text:
looking at digital enablement, we're looking
at using bleeding edge and open source technologies

2057.text:
to create a platform that we can share with
other local authorities, we're working with

2060.text:
thought works to train us up and get us into
a sustainable workforce but we are looking

2065.text:
to recruit in all roles to try and do something
different and obviously local authorities do good.

2073.text: Yes, other people please do recruit, yes.

2078.text: Who would like to ask another question?

2085.text:
I'm a lecturer at Salford city college and
we are currently in the process of going through

2091.text:
loads of ideas about creating apps to help
support online learning in the classroom - have

2096.text:
you got any recommendations of where to start
in that, if that makes sense?

2102.text: Of where to start in terms of...?

2105.text:
Research or any advice on how we can work
together to start working out how that's going

2112.text:
to work and the process of... The scary thing
is it's going to replace the classroom but

2119.text:
we really want it to work in harmony with
it, so working out how we can marry those

2125.text:
two together - have you got any advice? It's
all completely new and we're at the start

2130.text: so we're floating around at the minute.

2133.text:
Gosh there's a whole bunch of different answers
to that about where to start. I always start

2141.text:
by looking at what's already out there, both
in terms of what you can learn from that but

2145.text:
also could you just partner with somebody
who is already doing it?

2148.text:
As a former UX designer myself, as product
makers we are sometimes a bit guilty of thinking

2155.text:
that we should make a new product and that
we might make something better, I think technology

2159.text:
has moved on particularly in the last 5 years
to a place where there's a tool for about

2162.text:
80% of the things that we want to do and they're
generally pretty good in terms of experience

2168.text:
so I would always start by looking at what's
out there, making sure you've got a nice structured

2173.text:
set of reasons about why you should build
your own thing. If you decide that the things

2179.text:
out there aren't what you need. Again as a
former UX person the other place I start with

2185.text:
is research, I see people nodding, make sure
you really understand what your audience wants

2195.text:
from it first, particularly around apps, again
because we're guilty of rushing to make apps

2203.text:
and not really understanding what the route
to market is. And putting a good strong budget

2210.text:
case in for marketing your app if you're going
to be making one because apps without marketing

2216.text: are pointless. I hope that helps?

2230.text:
I've been working on a couple of universities
on some charity projects - we're a digital

2237.text:
interactive solution company. Working with
these universities and setting projects for

2247.text:
these students they've come back to us with
some really good ideas, where they can use

2252.text:
digital technology for good. We wanna know
which is the best way to take this forwards

2257.text:
in terms of communicating with the charities
in terms of finding the right people that

2263.text: we need to speak to initially?

2265.text:
Yeah it's a good question - I've worked with
over 80 different charities and great ideas

2271.text:
sometimes fail because they don't have senior
buy-in. I would say it depends a lot on who

2278.text:
you know at the charities and if you need
contacts if they're quite big charities I

2282.text:
might know someone there or someone who knows
someone there, but make sure you're talking

2287.text:
to whoever holds the purse strings because
anybody who works at a charity will tell you

2294.text:
I don't have enough budget for that. Unless
they're a small charity it isn't true, what

2298.text:
they mean is that they have a ringfenced budget
for their own personal bit that they struggle

2303.text:
to get outside of - what you need is the person
who has got the purse strings to the big budget!

2308.text:
They're the person to talk to and engage with
this.

2314.text: How closely are you working with the charities?

2316.text:
At the moment we've set the project, the students
come back and they've given us these great

2326.text:
ideas - we want to do this for free really.
But we need to speak to the right people so

2332.text:
we can get the project going and up to speed
asap.

2336.text:
So you need to get into the most senior person
you can is the honest. If it's digital stuff

2345.text:
whoever their head of digital is should be
interested particularly if you're doing it

2349.text:
for free, though I will say there's a real
danger of doing free work for charities or

2353.text:
pro-bono of any kind, pro-bono work often
isn't valued as much as work that is paid

2359.text:
for so if you're doing it for free, which
is a fantastic and wonderful thing that you're

2363.text:
doing make it really clear the equivalent
financial value that it would take to deliver

2369.text:
it, so that they understand the value of the
work that you are doing for them - I strongly advise that!

2378.text:
Thank you that's a great point actually Julie
on pro-bono.

2382.text:
Hi Julie, I work for a company called the
Satori Lab, we've been handing your report

2394.text:
to pretty much every client of ours - we usually
give it to the CEOs as they're the persons

2403.text:
who have the leverage to make those decisions.
One that pops up is the "Fire the nopers"

2410.text:
because when we find them entering the words
digital transformation they're usually in

2414.text:
the middle of some technology cycle and that
might involve really long contracts they can't

2420.text:
really get out of so I'm wondering what's
your go to answer for if you need to interrupt

2426.text:
the current technology process in order to
make the space for a proper digital transformation?

2432.text:
Good question and there's two answers - I
had this debate recently with the HR director

2439.text:
from the Royal Horticultural Society about
whether to do things under the radar and then

2442.text:
prove the success or whether to go in all
guns blazing and win the business case and

2446.text:
we sat on different sides - I think I come
very much from the background of doing things

2451.text:
quietly and proving the success. That was
very much what I learnt from working at the

2455.text:
BBC I don't know whether that's what other
BBC people here would say but I think it's

2463.text:
difficult with that point about the firing
the no person it's not something you can do

2467.text:
as an external party but you can shine a light
on their failings and how much they're holding

2474.text:
Certainly it's much easier to get agreement
for pilots and alpha iterations of stuff because

2482.text:
it's much smaller budgets, often small enough
budgets that don't require going through a

2488.text:
formal procurement process. If I'm meeting
resistance I will switch tact and say "Lets

2494.text:
just see if this works" asking people to experiment
is easier than asking them to commit.

2504.text:
Otherwise all you can do is keep working with
the most senior person there to help them

2508.text:
understand this. Honestly I think there are
going to be some non-profit organisations

2511.text:
that aren't going to make it through this
decade because they're going la la la about

2516.text:
it. I wish that wasn't true but it's something
that I found whilst doing the research for

2521.text:
new reality and I'm putting more personal
effort into the organisations that want the

2525.text:
conversation rather than fighting the ones
that don't.

2548.text:
Hello, I'm Matt, I read a lovely Medium post
a month or so ago by Courtney Martin which

2557.text:
was called the reductive seduction of other
peoples problems and I'm worried a bit that

2564.text:
in this rush to do good sometimes people think
that those problems are easier to solve than

2570.text:
they turn out to be so how do you make sure
that you're really engaging the people who

2575.text: really understand what the problems are?

2577.text:
Wow, yeah, you're right - I paint a picture
here like this stuff is easy but it's not easy.

2585.text:
There's a reason that there's resistance
to change in some non-profits, it's not just

2590.text:
that they have always done things in a certain
way, it's that those things that they've done

2594.text:
in a certain way have evidence that they do
work.

2598.text:
Again I think it comes back to the process
of experimentation I'm a big advocate for

2607.text:
investing and experimentation because otherwise
you're never going to know if there is a better

2610.text:
way of doing things. It might be that the
better way of doing things is one small thing,

2615.text:
it might be something as simple as ditch all
of your old crap office suite and move to

2621.text:
using Google Docs, something like that can
transform how effective an organisation is

2627.text:
internally therefore freeing them up to do
all of the great stuff that they already do

2631.text:
offline. I don't think digital and technology
is a replacement for everything in the non-profit

2636.text:
sector and you're right we need to be cautious
not to suggest that technology can solve everything

2642.text:
- for some organisations I think it can, for
other organisations what they do offline will

2648.text:
be and what they will always continue to do.
But there are things that you might think

2653.text:
were in that last camp that aren't, things
like international aid charities. The amount

2657.text:
of investment that goes into shipping aid
abroad it's phenomenally expensive. Until

2663.text:
recently we didn't have any alternative to
that but things like 3D printing are making

2667.text:
it possible to print supplies on-site. It's
still prohibitively expensive for quite a

2673.text:
lot of stuff but there's a lot of smart people
who know more than me who are saying that

2676.text:
they think in the next 10 years we'll be able
to print blankets, potentially some food supplies,

2684.text:
locally in the regions that they're needed
rather than having to ship them internationally

2689.text:
with all of the problems with corrupt governments
and allows access to the right people. I think

2695.text:
it's complex and it's very organisation specific,
there are things that technology can do that

2701.text:
are easy and are straightforward, there are
some things that technology can do to improve

2707.text:
things that are complex and will take time
and there are some things where actually technologies

2710.text:
role is just to help organisations operate
more efficiently which I think is universally true.

2732.text:
Hi Julie, I'm a final year student and I recently
published some posts on virtual reality, such

2740.text:
as the Hololens, could this be applied to
UX design, testing and in general?

2750.text:
Hololens is a virtual reality technology,
it can be applied to designing motorbikes

2754.text: and stuff or used in the UX industry.

2759.text:
I'm almost certain that the answer to that
is yes, but I'm not a VR expert. I think VR

2765.text:
is potentially exciting new technology, I
had a go on one of the very early Hololens

2770.text:
prototypes, it made me feel a bit sick! But
it was super cool, properly futuristic. There's

2777.text:
already a couple of organisations using VR
to do storytelling really beautifully, amnesty

2784.text:
and I will come back to your point - Amnesty
at one of their fundraisers with high value

2793.text:
donors, they gave them a quickly hacked together
VR headset to look at what was happening in

2805.text:
Syria in Aleppo a large city that's being
completely levelled and it was an incredibly

2815.text:
moving experience, more so than a traditional
video of the same thing, they raised twice

2821.text:
as much as they were expecting to as a result.
To come back to your point, there's an example

2828.text:
of where VR technology is being used to enhance
storytelling and I think the crossover between

2833.text:
user experience and content - if you're a
UX person and you don't think you're a content

2839.text:
strategist you're probably missing something.
I think there's something in that crossover

2844.text:
between UX and content where a new technology
like VR is probably something very fascinating

2850.text:
and you should do some more studying on that
and then tell the rest of us about it - I'd

2854.text:
be really interested if you do! Sorry I don't
have a magic answer but it's an interesting question.

2862.text:
Okay, Julie thank you very much that was a
perfect way to set the tone for the day so

2867.text: Please show your appreciation for Julie Dodd.
